Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Sometimes fighting inflation isn't even what, because it is so negligible? Choices:  A: economic instability B: not noticeable C: spend more D: rising interest rates E: boring<n><n>### Response:		E: boring<n>### Rationale:A: economic instability refers to the effect that a rising rate of inflation can have on a country's economy, so spending more in the face of inflation is not really fighting inflation, it just helps keep the economy alive.<n>B: Not noticeable: refers to the effect that inflation has on the average consumer<n>C: rising interest rates: inflation's relationship to the cost of credit which is usually tied to the rate of interest paid on that credit<n>D: It is not even noticeable, implies that the amount of increase in price does not change the rate of increase in inflation.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demetation:<n>Input:  Do you know what the best part of the best breakfast food? Choices:  "A": The crispy, "B": the fluffy  C: The deliciousness  D: E: The variety of foods<n>Answer" A<n><n>Input: Do you want to win this tournament or break down in the 16th round? Choices:  “A”: win it all  “B”: a tie  “C”: the final match “D”: go home<n>Answer: “B”<n><n>Input: What happens to food when it reaches room temperature even though it is on the shelf? Choices: <n>“A”: it is no longer edible  “B”: it’s not bad, but not really good “C”: it’s gone forever  “D”: it doesn’t matter<n>Answer:“A”: the “food” is not really food<n><n>### Response<n><n>-Instruction: Find the hidden value in the grid.<n>-Response:"109"<n><n>-Instruction-Fill in the words for each of the listed animals, and then fill in the missing words.<n>-In the middle: Snake Eel, Crab, Shark

Choices:  C: cake E: egg <n><n>- Input: Can a rooster get in your face and not cackle? <n><n>- Input Is it correct to have a hamburger while camping? <n><n>- The problem is what is a rooster, a hamburger, and a camping<n><n><n>### What does a "correct" answer mean?<n><n>- A correct answer is an acceptable solution based on the input. <n><n>- Input and output can be different, but acceptably.<n><n><n>### How would you grade student answers?<n>  - The input cannot be changed, but the answers to questions that are a part of the input can be changed, which would then change what is gradable.<n><n>  ### Can the answers also change?<n>  - If they don't have a choice of right or wrong, that's not interesting to me.<n><n>  ### What if the student's solution is only partially correct?<n>  - I would provide some guidance, but allow the student to provide a fuller answer.<n><n>### What else are students allowed to change?<n>  - They can change the question to ask for another answer.<n><n>  ### Is there a limit to how much a student can change?<n>  - The answer is open ended.<n><n>### Are student answers graded?<n>  - Yes they are, though there are instances when there are no right answers, in which case the system will just give the students credit for participating in the task.<n><n>  ### If there's no specific way to grade an answer, how do you determine if a student has done well or badly?<n>  - I will ask the student to explain the process through which the final solution was determined

Clone repo<n>2. Navigate to the /api<n>3. On the./api, run<n>```<n>npm install<n>npm start<n>```<n>4. Click "play"<n>5. Open postman<n>6. Select text body<n>6. Copy question and answer<n>7. Paste question and answer into Text body<n>8. Send request<n><n>## Links<n><n>* http://localhost:4200<n><n>The user questions are defined in user-questions.json

Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		The item must be polished or carved to show the reflection in it.<n><n>### Input:(A) What is a large lake where you can see many animals and birds? (B) What is the largest inland freshwater body of water in the world?  (C) What animals hunt on the lakes?  (D) Why is lakes an ecosystem?<n><n>### Response <n><n>To answer this question, you must know the answer to the questions above. <n><n>**(A)** A large lake where you can many animals and birds. **(B)** Lakes **(C)** It is where animals hunt **(D)** It is an ecosystem.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Jimmy didn't like going to the party.  It seemed like the guys there did nothing but what? Choices:  A: dance B: getting drunk C: meet new people D: having fun E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>The first two letters of the second phrase are the last letters of the first phrase. Use the letter, a letter a a letter b to complete the sentence.<n>The letters in alphabetical order.<n>J=I Y = M N = H P = R  U =S D=G B=V (I)<n>(Y)  (N)  (H)  (P)  (R)  (U)  (D)  (G)  (B) (V)<n><n>First phrase:<n>Jimmy didn' t like  going to the  party.<n><n>Second phrase:<n>dance getting drunk meet new people having fun<n><n>So in order to complete this the answer should be dance having fun.

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:If you are fiddling through a music book when you should be playing, you probably dont have? Choices:  A: practice B: dexterity C: idle time D: knowledge of music E: conductor<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A: practice B: idle time C: time D: conductor E: knowledge of music<n><n>---<n><n>```python<n>class Solution:<n>    def getExercisesFor(self, input1: str, input2: str):<n>  def stringify(thing)<n>    """Convert given value to a string."""<n>  """Convert given value to an int."""<n><n>  # @return the given value.<n>  def findPossibleWords(self, string):<n>    for i in range(len(string)):<n>      if string[i] == '-':<n>        if string[i+1] == '-' == True:<n>          if string[i+2] == '/' == True:<n>            print("Hahah it works!!!")<n>            word = string[i+2:i+5]<n>            print("The word is ", word)<n>            return word<n>      <n>```  <n>    <n><n>-----

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What is made out of only one piece? Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		C: puzzle box<n><n><n>### Review<n><n>1. What are the variables in this program?<n>   a. There is one variable that controls the number of questions: the amount of times, in `times`, to repeat the program. This is defined as `while x<times`.<n>   b. There is one variable defined as `choice`.<n>   c. The program works with integers, so a choice should be one of the choices.<n><n>2. What are the control statements in this program?<n><n>The main body is the `while` loop with `if` inside, so it is considered to be a loop.<n><n>3. What is the loop condition in this code?<n>   `if (choice == -1) { return;}`. This means that the loop ends when `choice` equals `-1`. This means when `choice` is a choice other than one of the available choices.<n><n>4. What is the function in this example?  <n>5. What is the return in this example?<n><n># Output<n><n>The output from this example is an object called `question`, which returns the answer to the question that is called when the variable `choice` is the index of the value in the table of available choices.<n><n># Modify Questions<n><n>To modify the code, add a call to the `question()` function in the program.<n><n># Hints<n><n>```c<n>question(x) {<n>    // Ask question<n>}<n>```<n><n># Output Task<n><n>## Write the value 7 after the line<n>```c<n>question = function(x) {<n>  // Ask question<n>  write("Question: " + question)<n>}<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```<n>Question: [ ]<n>```<n><n><n>## Write "A: " before the line<n>```<n>question = function(choice) {<n>  // Answer the question<n>  if(choic = -1) return<n>  write(question + " ") + choice<n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What does a person looking for new things in life do? Choices:  A: become depressed B: welcome change C: thank god D: experiences E: pay bills<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is A because they go through depression and find new things.<n><n><n>### Input<n>What is a good reason to wait until you pass someone to say Hi? Choices: <n>1. You will say it at the right time.<n>2. You don't know if they like you.<n>3. You don't want to seem bossy.<n>4. You don't have to say you're sorry.<n>5. You don't think you might be embarassing yourself.<n>       <n>### Response:<n>### Solution 1<n>The answer is 5 because you think that you might be embarresing yourself.<n><n>### Solution 2<n>The answer is 4 because you don't have to write you're sorry.

Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		<n>Furniture can go on all the answers, with the exception of `a`.  (Furniture can not go on a `roof`. A `roof` is on a `building`, which is an `a`partment.)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: Input: A bat is used as a sporting item. The first answer will always be a letter or string, and each following answer will have a greater answer that is closer to truth.<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Write a code which answers the question with the greatest value.<n><n>## Demonsration:<n>Input: What is the value of "x": ( x in my equation x - x ) / X - x? Answer: The answer will be in the value of `x`. (X - x) / (X - x) is in fact `X - X` which is '0'<n><n>## Demonstiaation:<n>input:A chameleon is a mammals.  What else can be mammals? Answer: a cat

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What happens when you take a shower after going for a run? Choices:  A: feeling refreshed B: becoming tired C: restlessness D: leg cramps E: sweating<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Part 1: The referee called... -> The referee called a...<n>The referee called for a... (e.g. time out, time race, penalty box)<n><n>#### Part 2: She wears... -> She wears...<n>She wears her... (e.g: spectacles, pants, tie, umbrella, slip)<n><n>#### Part D:What happens... ->What happens when you...? -> ->What happens when you......?<n><n>#### Part 4: What happens... -> -> What happens when you...?<n>(When you take a shower what happens?)<n><n>#### Part 5: What can you do with your eyes to avoid headaches?<n><n>#### Response:You can close your eyes or stare directly at the sun with sunglasses. <n><n>#### Part 6:<n>The sound of the waves can be heard when one stands on the beach.<n><n>#### Part 7: Who is the most famous pirate?<n><n>#### Response:: There are other, more famous pirates such as Blackbeard and Edward Teach.<n> <n>#### Part 8: He lives in a tiny apartment.<n>#### Response: People who live in small apartments share a restroom, kitchen and a hallway.<n> <n>#### References:<n>https://github.com/josephspellman/LingQ-sentence-formation<n><n>https://github.clementbc/Linguistics-TKA<n><n>https://github-clementbc/Lingq-References<n>

An employer should be able to consider everyone in the community for the job whether they have a background that is of poverty or wealth. <n><n>### Input Question:<n><n>### Response Question:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		B: bank at noon<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a function with the following parameters:<n><n>- int x<n>- int y<n>- int z<n><n>The function should return an integer.<n><n>### Function Definition<n><n>- int area(int x, int y, int z), returns a value representing 1,259,460<n><n>### Instrumentation:<n><n>Input: <n>```sql<n>DECLARE @Myintage INT;<n>DECLARE @Myincome INT;<n>DECLARE CUR_DATE DATE;<n>DECLARE @Resultant INT;<n><n>```<n>```sql<n>SET @Myintage = 27;<n>SET @Myincome = 23;<n>SET @Resultant = area(3, 4, 5)<n><n>BEGIN <n>IF @Resultant <> 1259460 THEN<n>RAISERROR('result is %d not equal to 1259k', 10, 2)  GO<n><n>END;<n>```<n><n><n>### Solution<n>```sql<n>IF CONVERT(VARCHAR, @Resultant)= '12594' BEGIN<n>RAISERROR('area value is 1259 not equal to 13') GO<n>END<n><n>IF CONVERT (VARCHAR, @Result = '0') THEN<n>RAISERROR ('error converting resultant to varchar') GO<n><n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		C: He would avoid being in the park.  Some places do not allow animals.  The pet shop allows pet sales and this could result in animal abuse. Also, pet stores that sell animals that are supposed to be pets are not as safe as just letting dogs take care of themselves.  Pet stores, like all animal warehouses, are stressful.  Not only this but having animals on your person is stressful.  When your going to an unfamiliar place, you might not find where you are or you may not have the knowledge of finding your way back.  On top of that, animal smell is also very unpleasant.  It is the same as an old schoolyard, but there is no smell in school.  The park is a place for wild animals so the animals may want to go there too.  It is in a wilderness, which is not meant to have humans present.  It is also important to note that the dog park is only for dogs.  Dogs are not supposed to interconnect with humans.  Last but not least, dogs may be in danger at the dog park.<n><n>### Input Where is it safe to play music? Choices: A: grocery store B: restaurant C: airplane D: living room E: park<n><n>In order to play a musical instrument, you need a private place and the best place to practice would be in your house.  Playing in public places can be a distraction to people in the neighborhood.  There is also a risk of hurting someone by playing loudly in their home and disrupting them from their daily routine.  The most obvious noise that comes from an instrument is your own voice while singing which is annoying.  Lastly, the most important reason is privacy.  You do not want people to see the instrument you are practicing with.  It might be embarrassing and hurt your self esteem.<n>

That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		Sarah thought that she had been gone all evening. Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>The person should pass the exam.<n><n>Answer: D: sticker<n><n>### Input<n>We should celebrate the victories we have.<n><n>### Response<n><n>We also celebrate the difficulties that we have to deal with. We need to appreciate the opportunities that we had or have.<n><n>Answer: E: avoid pain<n>### Input<n>You cannot do that!<n>### Response<n>How did you come up with that conclusion?<n><n>Answer: Live (a stringed instrument)<n><n>### Input :A: what can a baseball player do even though another player is in the penalty box? B: you cannot do that! C: how did you come to that conclusion? D: what does a referee check?<n><n>### Response A: a baseball player can get to the penalty box; B: this player is playing a wrong (or forbidden) rule; C: How did you (referee) know or come to the conclusion that that action (a player punched another player) was forbidden? D: a referee checks (several things such as) if rules are broken<n><n>Answer: D. what does a referee do?<n><n>### Input A: how do you make your decision if you think you know a lot about something? B: in a sporting event, what does the referee do? C: in a sporting game, who is the referee? D: how do the players play the game?<n>### Response A. make your decision based on what you consider reliable, accurate and valid sources B. referee the players. C. a referee (or umpire).  D. based on the rules they have agreed upon to play the game.<n><n>Answer: "A" : Make reliable sources into your decision.<n><n>### Input  A: what does a referees do during a hockey game? What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where in your home would you store birth control pills near your toothpaste? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: chemist's shop C: kitchen D: drug store E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		E E: bedroom<n>### Explanation: Birth control pills are classified as medicine, not toothpaste. If you are looking for something in your medicine cabinet, you will probably be looking in the bathroom which is a room in our home that is usually located in the upstairs. The kitchen is located in a different part of the home. The bedroom is just off of there. The kitchen may contain aspirins, cough medicine and other medicines. The bedroom would probably not contain any medicine shelves, like the medicine cabinet in the bathroom, but it surely would contain toothpaste! Therefore, I think that the correct response is "E: bedroom".<n><n>#### Expected response: E<n>

Choices:  A: work in life B: speak to people C: everywhere D: sitting ideal E: care for people<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In life people will be able to make money in many ways, such as being a doctor, lawyer, or politician. In the bible the people of Noah are told by God to " Be frugal, prudent, do not sin, and follow all the instructions of God."(Genesis:6:3). This means by being good we will be rewarded with more job opportunities through the course of life.<n><n>### Reference:<n>- [Sentence Completion](https://www.amazon.com/Sentence-Completion-Exercise-Book-Test-ebook/dp/B01M6C824X/ref=sr_1_fkmrnull_1?keywords=sentence+completion+book&qid=1563536952&sr=8-1-fkmrnull<n>

Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n><n>### Response:		D: New freedom<n><n>### Instructions and examples are adapted from [here](https://leetcode.com/explore/company-interviews/top-interview-questions-by-company/leetcode/2/))<n><n>### Hints:<n>If the instructions have multiple parts, then you can answer all parts of the questions in this same task.<n><n>### Notes:<n>1. The script, with the exception of the answer, should only depend on input.<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>If an answer is correct the program returns 1, if it is not, it will return 0.  You can test your program by running it with no input and the program will still respond.  <n><n>### Helpful Links:<n>* [Wikipedia - Multiple choice question](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_choice_question)<n>* [For Dummies - Multiple Choice](https://www.dummies.com/careers-money/education-careers/multiple-choice-questions-101/)<n><n>### Rubric<n>* Tests all input<n>* Correctly checks if their answer is correct (0/1)<n>* Readable<n><n>### Example<n>Here is an example from class of one of your completed tasks in the past.<n><n>### Code:<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>import sys # this package imports stuff that is already in the operating system<n><n><n>def main(argv):<n><n>    ## 1) If the program is called with no arguments, it should run the below<n><n>    ## 2) If the program is NOT called with no arguments, then it should require the user to fill in the blanks<n><n>    ## 3) The program should be able to handle any number of arguments. This means the user can call the script as many times as they want, giving it more, or fewer arguments as needed<n>    ## 4) The program should be as simple as it can be<n>    ## 5) The code that you write should not be able to be duplicated by the user<n>    ## 6) You program should be able to run on it's own, without any help from the user<n>    ## I think.  <n><n>    ## 7) Make the program run like this:<n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    if " ".join((str(arg) for arg in sys.argv[1:])) == '' or " ".join((str(" ".join((str(t) for t in sys.argv[2:

The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		Too many people want exotics snakes.  The supply of snakes in exotic environments is decreasing to fill the global demand. Exotic snakes in the wild are being captured and shipped to exotic pet shops. Demand for exotic snakes in pet shops is outpacing supply in local environments. The problem could be the global illegal sale of exotic snakes and not enough protection laws and enforcement for the supply of snakes.<n><n>### Input : If you eat a tiger, will it stay there forever? It will take much to solve the problem. It just can't handle it.<n>

Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		What might be the result of seasons skiing?  I think that broken bones could be the result of a long time of practice skiing.  Skiers also have to be in good physical condition to do a race or competency.  To train for a long time and keep up that stamina they would probably have to ski a lot.  Skiers sometimes get chapped lips, that is true, but usually those lips belong to beginners and not experts.  I don't think chapped lips is an issue for an expert skier.<n><n>This solution will need to be updated for the future. <n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:WHat do cats get into when they are ripping things apart? Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>def get_answer(a,b,c,d,e):<n>    if a=='A':<n>        if b=='B':<n>            if c=='C':<n>                if d=='D':<n>                    if e=='E':<n>                        return 'Country'<n>                    else:<n>                        return"Gotcha"<n>            else:<n>                return "Gotcha"<n>        else:<n>            return "Gotcha!"<n>    else:<n>        return "Gotcha!!"<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:A soccer field that is not contained in a building would be where? Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		B: mexico<n><n>### Input :What is the best way to make tea? Choices: <n>Answer:C: boiling water<n><n>### This is the third line of the instruction.<n><n>To help you understand how best to answer this problem it helps to read the problem statement again and try to identify keywords. (The first keyword that jumps out in the first example is nature. The referee called a �foul�, �players�, �penalty box�, and �penalty� are related to sports. Sigh and soccer do not relate to sporting events. The only thing in common in the question is nature.) <n><n>To write a code to solve this question we need to use the keyword "question". (Other keywords to consider are "answer", "input",  "output", "number", "option", and "choice".)<n><n>In computer science you will often be asked a series of questions in a programming language called *quizzes*. The answers to the questions will be the input to the code. That means you will need to use the keyword question.<n><n>The input to the code will be the questions that need to be answered together with the questions they match, which are called options. For this problem you only provided answers for two of the five questions. If you had provided answers for the other three questions, the instructions would be "question", input:"", options: ", " and output:".<n><n>When you code for a quiz you will need to create a loop, which will provide a choice for each question. The loop will need to be inside the input section, because the questions are required inputs to the code.<n>

Choices:  A: botanical garden B: doctor's office C: in a sea D: public place E: arboretum<n><n>### Response:		C: A special ficus can be found in a park.<n><n>### Input : Where might a special pig be found? Choices: 	<n>		  A: Offer to pick up the friend at the park B: Offer to drop the friend off at a store C: Offer to pick the friend up at the store D: Offer to call the friend a taxi <n>Answer: 	A : A person can pick up their friend at the park. <n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where is a note likely to indicate a melody? Choices:  A: fridge B: a classroom C: envelope D: medical chart E: sheet music<n><n>### Response:		<n>---<n><n>```python<n>from dataclasses import dataclass<n><n>@dataclass<n>class DataAnswer:<n>    input = None<n>    answer = None<n>```<n><n>#### Example<n>```python<n><n>class Example:<n>    def __init__(self, input = "park", answer = "C":):<n>        self.input = input<n>        self.answer = answer<n>```<n>#### Example<n>```<n>from dataclasses import field<n><n>from typing import Optional<n>```<n><n>class Example:    <n>    def __init__(*, input :"Where do humans go to be in nature?", answer = ():<n>        self.field = field(input)<n>    def __new__ (self,...):<n>        self.answer_type = type(self)<n>       ... <n>```<n>#### Example:<n><n>#### Example:<n>```python<n>from typing import Dict, List, Set<n>from typing import Optional, Union<n>```<n><n>#### Solution:<n>```python<n>solution = type(...)<n>```<n>#### Solution:<n>- In your solution, you should use an additional argument to define how you want your solution to look. <n><n>#### Solution: <n>I do not have any solutions as of this point in time.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>#### Solution: Include links to the following:<n><n>- Code example<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:People want to explore space, so what should they use to do it? Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		D, hoverboard<n><n>### Instructions:Add the response to the below response,<n><n>### Input1:<n>``` javascript<n>var get_input = function(input, options = function() { return true; }){<n>    let answer = input.toUpperCase();<n>    if(options(answer) === false){<n>        answer = prompt(input).toUpperCase();<n>        if(options(answer)){<n>            return get_input(input,options)<n>        }else{<n>            console.log("INVALID ANSWER");<n>        }<n>    }else{<n>        return answer<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input2:<n>``` javascript<n>get_response = function(input, choices) {<n>    let response = input;<n>    for(let x of choices){<n>        if(response == x){<n>           return x<n>        }<n>    };<n>    console.log("INPUT INVALID");<n>}<n>```<n>### Solution:<n>``` javascript<n><n>var get_input_2 = function(input, answers, options = function()  { return true; } ){<n>    let choice = input.toUppercase();<n>    for(let i=0; i < answers.length; i++){<n>        if(options([answers[i],input]) === false && choice.toUpperCase() === [answers[i], input]){<n>            choice = prompt(input).trim().toUppercase();<n>            if(options(option))<n>            {<n>                return get_input_2(input,answers,options)<n>            }else{<n>                console.log("INCOMETER ANSWER");}<n>        },} else {<n>            return choice<n>        };<n>}<n><n>get_input_2("Where do humans go in cities so that they are in nature? ",["movie theatre","university","park","Alaska","country"])<n>```

What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:An electronics store had things damaged from the rain, where should these things be stored? Choices:  A: large city B: strip mall C: building D: shopping mall E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Part 1<n><n>The correct answer is letter A "large city". It is a store and a business, they are doing business in a building, selling their items, that is a city.<n><n><n><n>#### Part 2<n><n>I would have used answer C if I was the store owner. The store owner is most likely a business owner so his answer will be as such. <n><n><n><n>### Reference:<n><n>https://education.microsoft.com/en-us/office-webapps-blog/creating-formulas-in-excel-2010-for-the-first-time-part-1/

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		You can exercise without sweating at all. However, when I sweat, I am working off energy. There is no other answer. Also, "vent" means to let off energy, but to do it audibly is not to "release energy" but to "exercise". In a sense, "venting" might be seen as an exercise, but it is not as we normally use the word "to exercise". Finally, "thinking" should have been acceptable, but to do it so hard that you sweat seems a little out there.<n><n>Answer: You can work off energy by venting your frustrations.<n><n>### Input<n>What is the sound a dog makes when it barks?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Answer: A: woof<n><n>### Input <n>What time does it take one heart muscle (heart) to pump blood?<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is roughly sixty seconds.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when in a race? Choices:  A: lay eggs B: eat fruit C: wrestle D: compete with each other E: draw pictures<n><n>### Response:		What do humans do when in competition A: lay eggs?<n><n>### Input Description: In a race humans compete with other humans in a fast competition.<n><n>### Input 2:What do humans do to have more fun when they have lots of time on their hands? Choices: 1: ride a bike 2: do chores 3: eat candy 4: draw pictures 5: watch a movie  <n><n>### Response 2: Humans have fun when they have lots pf time by watching a movie on the 1.14 hour 3:25 time line.<n><n>### Response Description: Time is written with Roman numerals. 9 am - IX A:M - AM/PM on a 24 hour clock is AM, PM, or noon. The letter A indicates the first quarter hour. 12:00 AM is in a time zone called Central Time Zone or "America/Chicago" in the time zone data for the world. There are 60 seconds in a minute, 60 minutes in an hour, and 24 hours in a day. One quarter of a day is in a time quarter called the 9th quarter hour which is abbreviated 3:25. Time is in the present continuous tense. This time is on a 24-hour clock. The time given is 2pm (14:00), and the question is what do humans do to have fun?<n>

Choices:  true: 8, false: 16<n><n>### Response (if true):<n>If there are 8 legs on the animal, it has 8 legs.<n><n>### Response(if false):<n>If there are more than 8 legs on the aniaml, it doesn't have 8 legs.<n>```python<n>if x is True:<n>```<n>### Instruction<n>```python<n>1. The first task is to convert each of the options to strings.<n>  Ex: answer A; answer choice 6:68<n>2. Read the prompt string as a whole<n>  Ex: If the ground is getting wet<n>    3. The if statement requires the truth value of the sentence<n>4. Output a string that you expect the user will enter.<n><n>```python<n>sentence = "If the ground is getting wett"<n>if sentence == "true" | sentence == "True":<n>```<n>### Demostration<n>```python<n>sent = "If the ground was getting wet"<n>answer = '8'<n>answer = str(answer)<n>sent = str("If the ground is " + answer)<n>print(sent)<n>```<n>### Inspire<n>How can you check if a string is True before the Python interpreter evaluates the condition?<n>

Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a shopping bag for packing groceries? Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is C: closet.<n>### The response should be formatted identically to the Input and Demonstration fields.<n><n>### Hints:<n>1. Each response must contain a sentence that answers the question.<n>2. This task is multiple choice only.<n>3. Response length is limited and no response input is allowed.<n>4. This is one of a series of questions on multiple choice questions and it may apply to any task that follows it.<n>5. After the response there will be a hint about this task. If the task is multiple choice, a hint will describe the format of each choice and what the correct answer may contain. You will not be able to see the hints during the test.<n><n>### Example Input: Input: Where can one find someone who will speak a foreign language to you? Choices: 1. A: traveler 2. B: shopkeeper 3. C: tour guide 4. D: teacher E: translator<n>1. The question is asking to list places where one can find someone who will speak to you in a foreign language.<n>2. Each place that will have someone who speaks the foreign language at a location listed is one choice on the multiple choice list.<n>3. To correctly complete the task, pick the correct answer from one or more of the choices listed.<n>4. Only traveler and translator are correct.<n>5. Tour guide, teacher and shopkeeper are not correct.<n>6. The multiple choice questions are in pairs. If a question has multiple choices like the example above, the other pair of choices will be a teacher and shopkeeper.<n>7. After completing a multiple choice task, there will be a hint.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: You have to move in a 1000 meter race and you see a 100 meter section of ground in 8 minutes. How long is the race in total? Choices: <n>1. A: a full day  2. B: 20 minutes  3. C: 8 hours  4. D: 2 hours  5. E: one and a half hours<n>Output: Answer: C:8 hours<n><n>### Demostration<n>Step 1: Input one digit into the calculator<n>Step 2: Multiply the number by the other digit<n>Step 3: Add one<n>Step 4: Enter the

Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a coastal, gulf state, where is this person? Choices:  A: alabama B: louisiana C: south carolina D: arkansas E: mountains<n><n>### Response:		I believe that this request was referring to the city of Gulf Shores, Alabama - which is a coastal, gullet state.  It's about a 38-41 mile drive depending on where you live.  Gulf Shores is a small city that doesn't really have much to brag about as far as business goes.  However, it is a great place to live and work.  It is the perfect beach vacation destination.  We've been going here for years.  What it has has always been the sandy beach that makes it awesome and of course the great people.  I also love the fact that you can rent a bike and ride alongside the beach in the Gulf Coast National Seashore area.  I live about two hours away and try to get there at least once a month.<n><n>## 759-B:Design a question to ask another student<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes how to answer a question. Write a request that appropriately completes that instruction.<n><n>### Concept:You have the ability to create two sets of three statements: two true and one false. For each statement, you must identify the one true statement. Select four options.<n><n>### Write a response that appropriates completes the request. <n><n>### Instructions:You may type or use the voice feature of your computer to speak.  After listening to your response, a judge will respond with the appropriate response.  When the system detects that you have finished answering the question, it will speak an appropriate response.<n><n>### Response option 1<n><n>- The first number is odd.<n>- The first number has an odd number of digits.<n>- The first two statements are false. <n><n>## Response option 2<n><n>- The second number is even.<n>- The second number has an even number of digits.<n><n>## Response option3<n><n>### Question:Is any number even when the sum of it's digits is odd?<n><n>## Response 1<n><n>- In this situation, an even number would be odd.<n>- Another even number would be even. <n><n>## #759-c:Design a Question<n><n>### Question 1:When I was reading this book, I was thinking about how I should give it to you. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where are you likely to find a paper program? Choices:  A: theater B: computer C: opera D: television E: concert<n><n>### Response:		<n>C.<n>  <n>In the 21st century, people are less likely to find a paper  program at a modern concert as opposed to a 20th century concert.<n>A modern concert will likely include both an online and print program via an app, rather than a paper one in the lobby of a building. An opera, however, is still a  classical form of performance art, and so is far more likely to include a traditional paper program.<n><n>A paper program would still be offered at a concert venue in the 21stcentury, but would be a lot rarer. <n>

Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		A & B: Both cabinet and computer are computer not for sale<n><n>### Instructions: Answer each of the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Response format: In the response box, answer each of following multiple choice questions. Be sure you put the words "a" and "b" after each answer.<n>### <n>### Instruction1: What are things that are inedible but edible? <n>### A: Scabs B: Eggs C: Chestnuts D: Bees E: Eyeballs<n>### Response: Both answers: E and D.<n>### Instruction 2: What do you keep on while using something? <n>### <n>A: Wearing hats B: Wearing underwear C: Wearing shirts D: Wearing pants E: Wearing skirts<n>F: Putting on jackets<n>### Response: Answer A, B, D are wearing.<n>### Instruc3: What do you turn on to get hot tea? Choices:<n><n>A: Stove B: Grass C: Fire D: Kettle E: Oven<n>A: Stove, C: Fire and D: Kettle<n><n>### Instinct: What do you look at to find objects in three dimensions?<n>A: The back of your hand. B: Pitcher. C: Computer screen. D: A book. E: A kettle.<n>A: The back or your hand.<n><n>### Intuition: Where do you take a vacation from work?<n>A: Work place. B: Country. C: Cottage. D: The beach. E: Office<n>E: Office<n>### Instruct: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>### Demo<n>### Counterintuitive: When is a timepiece an incorrect timepiece?<n>### A: In the morning B. During the night<n>Answer: A in the midday<n><n>### Counterinuitive: When do you do a thing wrong?<n><n>### Answer: A: Night B: Early morning<n><n>### Coutinstinctive: What is not the only way to turn someone off?<n><n>### Demo: A: Shake someone's hand. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:There was a saucepan used only for marinara, where was it kept? Choices:  A: georgia B: the south pole C: kitchen cupboard D: italian restaurant E: boil eggs<n><n>### Response:		The saucepan can was found next to marinara.<n><n>```bash<n>    while read -r line && [ $? -eq 0 ]; do <n>        IFS=$'\n' read -r -a a <<< "$line"<n>    echo -en '\x1b[${a[0]}m'<n>    echo -ne '${a[1]}'<n>    echo -en '${a[3]}$' <n>    done <<< "answer the following multiple choice question."<n>    done<n>            cat answer_the_following_multiple_choice_question.sh<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n><n>```bash<n>(1) where do humans go in cities  <n>                         to be in nature? a: movie theatre b: university c: park d: alaska e: country<n>(3) the referee called a fowl when one player punch another player. the player was sent to the penalty box.  <n>                         what game are they playing? a: sporting event b: time race c: part two boxer? <n>                         d: football e: hockey game<n>(3) what kind of breathing makes noises  <n>                         but do not indicate that you are <n>                         sick? a: sigh b: clavicular c: yawn <n>                         d. cough e: light<n>(3) what you wear the bridge of your nose a: scar<n>                         b: tunnel c: transportation system <n>                         d spectacles e: stringed instrument.<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:The shelf was showing signs of instability, what should the carpenter fix to avoid any issues? Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```java<n>package com.javarush.task.task15.task1518;<n>import java.io.*;<n>import java.math.*;<n>import java.util.*;<n><n>/**<n> * Created by javarush on 04.11.2017.<n> */<n>public class Solution {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {<n>        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));<n>        Process process = null;<n>        String line = reader.readLine();<n>        String[] parts = line.split("\\s+");<n>        for (String part: parts){<n>            System.out.print(part + "\t");<n>            process.write(part.getBytes());<n>            process.flush();<n>        }<n>        line = reader.read Line();<n>    }<n>}<n><n>```<n>

What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n><n>Sentences = input().split()<n><n>#if Sentence > 1:<n>for i in range (len(Sentences)):<n>    Sentences.remove(i)					#removing the index number						<n>	if Sentences[i] == "A" :<n>		print(i)<n><n>```<n>

Choices: 1) large A: poodle B: collie C: terrier D: spaniel E: shar pei<n>2) medium A: coyote B: coon C: doberman D: pit bull E: wolf<n><n>### Response.2 A: coon <n><n>#### Input: Which of these objects will fall through the hole in the bottom of the box with only a hole on the side of the box? Choices: <n>1) A) box of feathers B) block of wood 2) C) bowling ball<n>D) sheet of stiff paper. E) 20 pounds<n><n>#### Response: 2) D: sheet of stiff paper<n><n>### Input<n>1.  I'm a boxer because my job is to hit, punch, and throw and get hit.<n><n>2.  I'm watching you.<n><n>3.  I'm on TV.<n><n>4.  I live here.<n><n>### Response<n>1.  A.boxer<n><n>2.  B.watching<n><n>3.  C.on<n><n>4.  D.live<n><n>#### Input:How many animals have four legs but they are different?<n><n>#### Response: C: dog and cat.<n><n>#### Input: which country is in the Northern Hemisphere? Choices:<n>A: africa B: australia C: china D: europe E: north america<n><n>#### Response: E: north america.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:If children get confused walking home where may they go? Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		What is the meaning of ‘to gettable’?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a function called gettable. To be considered complete, this function should meet the following requirements:<n>- It must return a true value.<n>- It must return the string “the house” if they end up at the right place.<n>- It must reject a false value that indicates they went the wrong way.<n>- It must display a message that appropriately describes what’s happening, if the program rejects a value.<n>- It may display a message that appropriates describes what’s, if the program returns a true value.<n><n>Here’s an example call of gettable, that might include additional information and/or questions depending on how your function reacts:<n><n>```javascript<n>gettable = function() {<n>  // Your program code goes here<n>}<n><n>gettable();<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Gettable = () => {};<n><n>### Your submission<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? There is one correct response per statement.<n><n>### A: How can something be considered an art for millions of years without ever having been considered art? Choices:  (1) We like it very much.  (2) We feel no admiration for it.  (3) We have never heard of it.  (4) Because it is in fashion.  (5) Because we prefer one thing to another.  (6) It is not something that we would like to try.  (7) We find no purpose for it in our lives.<n><n>### Answer: 1 & 2<n><n>### B:  When you say there is nothing to do because everything has been tried before, and you have found them all to be wrong, what did you call them? And when you do, you should know why. Choices: (1) Everyone should know why before they make a decision. (2) No one should know what to decide. (3) There are no right or wrong things to decide. Choices:  A: math book B: phonebook C: statistic D: music school E: office<n><n>### Response:		You can learn about the operations with numbers in a book called "math". Or, some people learn it in math school.<n><n>**NOTE:**<n><n>The response must appropriately answers the request of the instruction. So, the response should end as a full sentence. For example, the instructions ask what game do two players are playing for? The response can be: "E: hockey game". Notice, the period is not an incomplete word. The period ends the response as a full sentence. If the response ends with "?", it is not a full sentence. Also, do not respond to the example questions at the request of the request. The request is: "Demonstrate how to..."<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where should an excavation never take place? Choices:  A: construction site B: cemetary C: building D: city E: archeological site<n><n>### Response:		<n>* You need to specify what kind of construction. Like if it was a road, then yes you have to call the site or excavation a construction site. But like if it was landscaping or building of a house I would guess that would not be a construction site since it is not a road of a street. It is a bridge between a structure that needs to built and the foundation of the building. But maybe the foundation of the building is just a simple pole holding it together.<n><n>* It is up to the person to pick where the archeological dig is on the list of places they are asking about. If they chose one of the places you would recommend they did not pick that place, then they should not dig there. It is up to the site manager to approve or disapprove of the idea of digging in this place.<n><n>Response:<n>* What a terrible idea to ask a question like this. It could be that the archeological site is right where the construction site is located. It just does not mean they will need to excavate the archeological site. They might just need to find that they were going to do some kind of demolition and they would hit up against the archeological site and the archeologist would tell them they may not do a excavation in this place<n><n>Input: What is the best way to find the largest group in a large country? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have thousands of statue? Choices:  A: church B: theatre C: large city D: water fountain E: central park<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import sys<n>sys.stdin.readline()<n>texts=['Where do','The referee','What kind of','What do you','What kind of place']<n>def find(strings,input):<n>    strings=input.split()<n>    #iterating through the strings<n>    for temp in strings:<n>      #if temp is equal to string passed in the argument<n>      if temp in strings:<n>        return temp<n><n>def replace(strings,input): pass<n>```<n><n>### Outputs:<n>```python<n>>>><n>```<n>### Testing:<n>```<n>from __future__ import print_function, division<n><n>def replace(s,words):<n>    """<n>    Find every element of s, and replace it by its word from words<n>    """<n>    for word in words[:]:<n>        if word in s[:]:<n>            s[:]=s[:].replace(word,word)<n>    return''.join(s)<n><n># Example Usage<n>print(replace('Mary had a little lamb',['lamb','Mary','little','a', 'had'])) <n>```<n>### Credit:<n>**Source: https://www.analytictech.com/python/examples/find-and-replace.htm**<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Your solution:<n>*/<n>'use strict';<n><n>const fs = require('fs')<n>const args = process.argv.slice(2)<n><n>if (!args.length) {<n>  fs.writeFileSync('output.txt', '')<n>}<n><n>const outputFile = 'output.txt';<n><n>const solution = fs.existsSync(outputFile)<n> ? fs<n>   .readFile(outputFile)<n>   .toString().trim()<n>   .split('\n')<n>   .filter(line => line.trim()!== `$`)<n><n>   .shift()<n>  : fs.appendFile(outputFile, fs.readFileSync(process.argv[1]));<n><n>const solutions = fs.readFileSync('data').toString().trim().split('  ')<n><n>if (solutions.find(part => part.indexOf('your solution.ext') > -1)) {<n>  return<n>}<n><n><n>let isSolution = (string) => {<n>  const stringRegExp = /[^A-Za-z0-9-:]/g;<n>  return string.match(stringRegExp);<n>}<n><n>solutions.push(`Your solution: ${solution.match(/^your (.?)\.ext/)[1]}`);<n><n>fs.writeFileSync('data', `${solutions.join('  ')}`);<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:This city in Northern Norway is filled within things to do like Polar Nights half marathons and located in the middle of the Northern lights oval, which city is it? Choices:  A: northern B: nome C: tromsø D: finnmark E: vadsø<n><n>### Response:		Tromsø is filled with half marathons, and is located in the Northern lights oval. Tromsø, Norway.<n><n>**NOTE:** I have never taken an AI programming class, but the teacher suggested I create this in English, which is my second language, which caused me to miss some spelling and syntax issues.<n><n>**NOTES:**<n><n>### I:<n>```<n>In the first question, the code for park is E, which was wrong and the answer was C. The teacher said I should always look for multiple spelling variations of a word.<n>```<n><n>### II:<n>```<n>In this question the code for hockey is A, but the teacher said that I should look at every letter separately for a question.<n>```<n><n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a theater which only has unpaid actors? Choices:  A: shopping mall B: hospitals C: populated area D: school E: military base<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I think that you are talking about a _reconaissance_ base. Reconaissance bases usually only have _unpaid_ actors.<n><n>I would recommend that you take an unpaid actor to the _populated_ area of the _school_ where you are a paid acting instructor. <n><n>You might want to have them put on a _costume_ for your acting class and then they could _perform_ in the _theater_ at your school.<n><n>### Input 2:Where could you find an actor which also sings? Choices: 	A: unemployed B: unpaid C: understudy D: employed E: undressed<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>That actor might be in a _play_, _opera_, or _concert_.<n><n>Their song might be a part of their _opera_ performance at the _musical theatre_.<n><n>This is an example of a _crossover actor_ because they are singing a song in a _concert_.<n>

Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:She wanted to make a quilt of velvet, where should she look? Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		she should look in the fabric store.<n><n>### Answer:<n>A: Grandma doesn't have any velvet, so that's not a viable source.<n>B: She wanted to make a qulut of velvet, but clothes are just fine.<n>C: Jewelry store doesn't have any cloth at all.<n>D: Clothes are not made of velvet and a fabric store IS a clothing store so..<n>E: A fabric store has velvet..but it's a B!<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Question:What is the best way to measure time? Choices: 1: clock 2: o'clock<n>Answer: 1: clock<n><n>### Input <n>Question:What is a famous statue in New York City? Choices: 2: man statue 3: liberty statue 4: statue of liberty 5: statue of liberte 6: statue of life 7: statue of liberty<n>Answer: 3: statue of liberty<n><n><n>### Answer<n><n>A. Yes, the two choices are correct, it doesn't matter which one you pick.<n>B. The answer should be 2 o'clock because clocks are a good way to measure time.<n>C. It's the Statue of Liberty, but it's a bit less famous.<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Answer the folling multiple choice question. In what room would you find a book? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>|Input|Oulput|Description|<n>|---|---|---|<n>|A|Carton|A chicken coop is a farm structure that is used as large indoor enclosures for housing chickens. Eggs are not bought from the chicken coop but rather from the supermarket or from the farmer directly.|<n>|B|Supermarket|Because the eggs are kept and sold in the supermarket, they are not kept in a carton|<n>|C|Box|Because the box is where the eggs are kept after they are purchased, they are contained in the box|<n>|D|Carton|Cartons are not used to keep eggs but rather to contain them|<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demo:<n>Input: What type of bird stands and walks like a man? Answer: A: human<n><n>## Response:<n>|Input |Output |Explanation |<n>|---|--- |--- |<n>|A | Human | Because the description includes the words "like", it means that there is some element that this bird posses that resembures a human. This bird, in this question, is only a man. It could also be an ape.|<n>|B | Bird | Because the description includes "stands" and "walks" which describe movements, it could be assumed that the bird would be a regular bird that flies.|<n>|C | Bird | Because the first sentence includes that it stands and walks like humans, it is likely that the second sentence is describing a robot|<n>|D | Human | Because the first sentence is specific to a bird, it is less likely to believe that the second sentence is referring to a robot. It seems more appropriate that the second sentence is a description of humans because everything that the question poses is something that a bird is described to have and human are the only group of these characteristics.|<n><n><n>### Instrection:Answer the following multiple option question.<n><n>## demo:<n>Input: What do bees do but horses do not? What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		The lake is the correct answer<n><n><n>### Input A: The city of Boston has no natural source of drinking water because it is located on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean.  It does get water from the Charles River.  Where does the Charles River get its water? Choices: a: Atlantic Coast b: Charles River c: Long Island Sound d: Charles River e: Potomac River<n><n>### Request Answer:<n>#### The Charles River gets its water from the Chelsea water treatment facility.<n><n>#### Instructions: Answer:<n><n>* Input: The earth quake occurred in Mexico City on the 19th of September during the month of October. Choices: A: September B: October C: 19 D: Saturday E: Earth Quake.<n>* Request: How did you know the date was the 22nd of October?<n><n>#### Response:<n>The date came from a 2018 tweet by the US Geological Survey.  We know that occurred in Mexico since the date came from a tweet by the USGS, the date came from the text of the tweet.  Based on the date we know the date is during the month of October or else the tweet would not have come from the USGS.  The date (22nd) only occurred on the the 22nd and 22nd of the month of October and only on those dates.<n><n>It is likely that some of these dates had typos.  There is no information about why the date is different, but the date of the day is different and the date was tweeted.  In other words, the date came from a 4:00 AM tweet.<n><n>#### Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question by selecting the correct answer from the choices.<n><n>* Select the correct answer from the options below.<n><n>#### Request Answer:<n><n>#### Input: The earthquake in Mexico occurred on the 22nd day of October. The earthquake happened on 22nd day? Choices: a : Yes b: no<n><n>### Demostration Input: The earthquakes on October 22nd in Mexico occurred on 22nd of Oct. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>Input: The referee called a foul when one player punched another.  The player went to the penalty box. What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:The man needed to buy flooring, where was he looking for it? Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: walmart<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The answer is 'walmart.'<n>We must have a person,'man.' We found that'man' in'man needs to buy flooring.'<n>Then we have the location, place 'where.'<n>All the choices are places, house, walmart, home depot, and kitchen.<n>The choice that doesn't fit is kitchen because'man' doesn't need kitchen stuff.<n>The last piece of information is the thing that you can buy from a place.<n>You can choose 'Walmart' because 'Walmart' offers 'Flooring.'<n><n>### Input<n>### Response<n>We would like to buy bread, where should we go? Choices:  B: bakers market C: supermarket A: street Vendor D: convience/grocery<n><n>### Explantion<n><n>We would like to have bread.<n>The 'where' in the question is always the place that you can buy.<n>The word'market' tells that you can buy 'bread' in the place that has'market'.<n>Markets are bakers' market, supermarket, and convience/gourcery<n>baker's market and convience/grocer are not the right things, because we didn't mention that we are looking for the bread that we would like to buy.<n><n>### Input <n>### Response<n>Where do humans eat? Choices:  E: outdoors F: outside lunch B: indoors G: kitchen<n><n>## Explanation<n>We need 2 pieces of information<n>1. Person(s) which humans in general<n>2. Place(s) which humans can eat in.<n><n>### Response<n>A: B:<n><n>### Explantion<n><n>A is the correct answer because humans don't eat 'outside'.<n><n>B is the correct answer because Humans do eat food 'inside'.<n>Humans eat food all around the world, like we do. So, 'indoors' is not the correct choice.<n>

What game are they playing? Choices:  A: sporting event B: time race C: part two boxers D: football E: hockey game<n>Answer: E: hockey game<n><n>Input: What kind of breathing makes noise but does not indicate that you are sick? Choices:  A: sigh B: clavicular C: yawn D: cough E: live<n>Answer: A: sigh<n><n>Input: What do you wear on the bridge of your nose? Choices:  A: scar B: tunnel C: transportation system D: spectacles E: stringed instrument<n>Answer: D: spectacles<n><n>### Input:You might head to the locker room after getting a green drink here. Choices:  A: health club B: jocks C: fitness centre D: stadium E: gymnasium<n><n>### Response:		The word “after” in the instruction indicates a future tense is requested. The word “locker” in the input contains the letters “lo” and when rearranged gives the order “O L” and when rearranging the letters gives the word “out.” To answer this question and get the green drink from the gymnasium, you must go out and get it at the gymnasium.<n><n>### Input:- The sun is out. Choices:  (I): The moon is out. (II):The earth is out. (III):The stars are out. (IV):The aliens are out. (V):Everything is out. (X): A: None of the above B: None of the above C: All of the above D: There is no such thing as the sun E: All of the above<n><n>### Response:- The moon, the earth, the stars, and the sun are all “out” after the word “and” in the last choice.<n><n>### ACT<n>### If the player at the point guard position gets a bad cut then he can’t get to the basket from here.<n>
